subject: Only one instance of a test class (was: Re: [junit] How JUnit runs test class)
msgSnippet: Sorry, I had promised to reply on the original thread, but it turns out that Kent solved the original poster s problem while I was talking about something
messageBody:
Sorry, I had promised to reply on the original thread, but it turns
out that Kent solved the original poster's problem while I was talking
about something else. Glad that worked out, Vietchau.

On to the side discussion:

On 12/22/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > Here's the code sample. The code for OneInstance was in my last
> > e-mail. Only one instance of HumongousDataStructure is constructed.
>
>
> Yes, and you are still using a static variable for this example:
>
> public class ConstructOnceTest {
> public static class HumongousDataStructure {
> static int numConstructed = 0;
>
> How would you do this without a static?

Good grief! (To use a seasonal phrase)

I actually considered putting in a disclaimer before the original code
sample, but I thought it was redundant. The point is this line:

private HumongousDataStructure thisTakesAReallyLongTimeToConstruct =
new HumongousDataStructure();

Here, our HumongousDataStructure is declared as an instance field, and
is only constructed once. I thought this was what we were talking
about.

numConstructed, on the other hand, is being used to "test the test".
It is a static variable because I wanted to find out how many
HumongousDataStructures were constructed globally. Do you have a
favorite, clear way to do this without using a static variable?

I fear that if this discussion is left to rhetorical flourishes, I am
without the ammo and desire to prevail. Let's get down to declarative
statements.

Cedric, I believe that using the @RunWith(OneInstance.class)
annotation, any JUnit test class will be run in such a way that only
one instance of the class is constructed for all methods invoked, and
therefore, each instance field will be assigned only once. Do you
believe that I am mistaken?

David Saff
